I would restructure this so that we can grab unspecified platforms as well as known platforms.
This does not return a List, it returns an Iterable
`.toList`? (and update the first type)
I find the current implementation quite easy to follow, leaving it as is.
else not needed.
else not needed.
If `yaml['platforms']` is not a `YamlMap`, then this call will throw a runtime type error. Please add a check, and return an error instead.
ditto. Check the type of `yaml[AndroidPlugin.kConfigKey]` etc. and add appropriate error messages.
This is the actual change, everything else is tests.
Consider giving a pointer back to here and/or explaining how to generate it or where it came from.

comments.body: Should we only instantiate this if there is at least 1 old plugin?
It would probably be a good idea to check accepted values here and throw an appropriate error if a bad value is passed in.
Swift plugins should not need to add an Objective-C header if they don't need it.

comments.body: Unrelated to this PR, just curious - would it be possible / make sense for the logic here and in _getEmbeddingVersion in `platform_plugins.dart` to be the same? (seems like one is deciding based on a manifest key and the other based on Java imports?)

We don't have the app's main class name in pubspec.yaml, so that would require an extra hop. One possibility is that we get the main app class/package from `AndroidManifest.xml` and then check the import in the java class.  That would still require to parse the XML file.
@zoeyfan to double check on the wording here.

comments.body: Do we have docs/wiki/website we could link to in this error message?

Added the placeholder link for the new schema documentation (https://flutter.dev/docs/development/packages-and-plugins/developing-packages#plugin).
We're tracking writing this section in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/44287 I plan to do it this week. I'd like to not wait for the link to be ready before landing this in case there's a chance this will make it to next stable.

This will capture direct dependencies, but not transitive dependencies - is this an issue?. Consider:

plugin A depends on package 1
package 1 depends on plugin B

.flutter-plugins will contain plugin A/plugin B while the dependencies file will not link them.

From offline discussion, this isn't a supported use case - and that platform code cannot depend on eachother. Therefore it doesn't seem like the gradle task ordering needs to take this into consideration

Isn't the location of this line in the file going to be "random" (not from run to run unless the map implementation changes, but not guaranteed to be first)? I don't have a solution that doesn't break existing apps since we're re-using a file that's already a dictionary--otherwise we could wrap the real content in an array with the comment then the content--but I'm wondering how useful this will end up being without an order dependency. I guess better than nothing...
I changed the test to not require an order comparison and clarified in the comment that the order is not guaranteed
Is the plan to split "dependencyGraph" per platform in a separate PR?

I don't think it makes much sense to split it anymore. It doesn't really add any value. I started that way, but then we'd have change the way the dependencies are handled in gradle, which at that point felt unnecessary. What do you think?

Gradle is working around the fact that `dependencyGraph` isn't split per platform.  I think it would be ideal if Gradle didn't have to workaround that and instead just read this file. This could be done in a separate PR though if that makes sense.
Makes sense, I did it here :)
nit: file a bug for this TODO if there isn't one already.
This logic had to be updated. It was always returning true, since date_created was always different on each file. This caused the podfiles to be invalidated every time.
